{{Community}}
The term '''snapshotting''' refers to the state in which attributes are fixed on a long-lasting ability, effect, entity, or summon based on the character's attributes during the ability's activation. A snapshotted ability will not receive the additional buffs the character obtains after its activation.

For example, [[Xiangling]]'s [[Pyronado]] will receive the [[Attack|ATK Bonus]] for the entirety of its duration when cast inside [[Bennett]]'s [[Fantastic Voyage]] field &mdash; even if Xiangling walks outside the buff's area of effect or it expires prematurely. However, the ATK Bonus will not affect Pyronado if cast before Bennett's Fantastic Voyage - regardless of whether Xiangling stays in the buff's area of effect.

In some cases, weapons can also snapshot their own effects. For example, a bow that increases attack on a weak spot hit may increase the attack of the hit that triggered this effect.

==Buffs==
Buffs are effects that improve a character's ability or attributes. While they can arise from character talents, constellations, artifact sets, weapon passives, or other external sources.

* '''Static Buffs''' - The buff does not scale off any attribute, or if the attribute which the buff scales off changes during the buff's duration, the buff ''will not'' change.
* '''Dynamic Buffs''' - If the attribute which the buff scales off changes during the buff's duration, the buff ''will'' change.

* '''Direct Buffs''' - Buffs that do not modify the damage dealer's attributes, and instead directly apply to real-time damage calculations. These buffs are completely unaffected by snapshotting. This is a separate concept from Static and Dynamic Buffs and coexists with them.

==Talents==
Talents are character abilities that can receive static or dynamic buffs. While there are several talents that can be intuitively determined to be non-snapshottable, some are not - as such, it is important to clarify and distinguish the two types:

*'''Snapshottable Talents''' - Attributes are fixed after an ability's activation.
*'''Non-Snapshottable Talents''' - Damage is recalculated during every instance of the ability's activation based on the character's current attributes.

<u>Note:</u> Most talents that were not included do not have a delay on their damage or effects upon their activation. Non-Snapshottable talents isn't an exhaustive list but is used to provide clarity to some talents that may have similar mechanics but do not snapshot.

==Elemental Reactions==
Primarily, the previous sections only take account physical or elemental damage from character abilities. Reactions have a dependency [[Elemental Mastery|elemental mastery]], but depending on its type it may or may not snapshot.

Starting from [[Version 1.4]], the snapshotting of [[Elemental Mastery|elemental mastery]] for transformative reactions such as [[Electro-Charged]], [[Overloaded]], [[Shatter]], [[Superconduct]], and [[Swirl]] was removed, and replaced with real-time damage calculations. Therefore, transformative reaction damage bonus from elemental mastery buffs gained after an snapshottable talent's activation is still gained even after its activation - increasing damage of the talent. In short, order or timing is no longer an issue and is only limited by the buff's duration.

For example, the [[Superconduct]] damage triggered by [[Ganyu|Ganyu's]] [[Celestial Shower]] will be boosted by [[Sucrose|Sucrose's]] [[Catalyst Conversion]] even after Ganyu's talent is cast. Prior to the version changes, the Superconduct damage would only be boosted if Sucrose's talent was triggered before Ganyu's burst.<ref>HoYoLAB: [https://www.hoyolab.com/article/https://www.hoyolab.com/article/256800 Explanations of Some Fixes in the Version 1.4 Update]</ref>

*'''Amplifying Reactions''' (Melt and Vaporize) - Bonus elemental mastery can be snapshotted to snapshottable talents, but are fully bound to its limitations.
* '''Transformative Reactions''' (Electro-Charge, Overload, Shatter, Superconduct, and Swirl) - Bonus elemental mastery bypasses snapshotting entirely.

In summary, the amplification reaction damage bonus resulting from buffs to elemental mastery can be considered to be a <u>static buff</u> while the transformative reaction damage bonus resulting from the same buffs can be considered to be a <u>dynamic buff</u>.
